description.p: A bastard sword is too large to use in one hand without special training; thus, it is an exotic weapon. A character can use a bastard sword two-handed as a martial weapon.
You strap a shield to your forearm and grip it with your hand. A heavy shield is so heavy that you can’t use your shield hand for anything else.
Wooden or Steel Wooden and steel shields offer the same basic protection, though they respond differently to special attacks.

Shield Bash Attacks You can bash an opponent with a heavy shield, using it as an off-hand weapon. See Table: Weapons for the damage dealt by a shield bash. Used this way, a heavy shield is a martial bludgeoning weapon. For the purpose of penalties on attack rolls, treat a heavy shield as a one-handed weapon. If you use your shield as a weapon, you lose its AC bonus until your next action (usually until the next round). An enhancement bonus on a shield does not improve the effectiveness of a shield bash made with it, but the shield can be made into a magic weapon in its own right.

You need at least two hands to use a bow, regardless of its size. You can use a shortbow while mounted. If you have a penalty for low Strength, apply it to damage rolls when you use a shortbow. If you have a bonus for high Strength, you can apply it to damage rolls when you use a composite shortbow (see below) but not a regular shortbow.
An arrow used as a melee weapon is treated as a light improvised weapon (-4 penalty on attack rolls) and deals damage as a dagger of its size (critical multiplier ×2).
Arrows come in a leather quiver that holds 20 arrows.
An arrow that hits its target is destroyed; one that misses has a 50% chance of being destroyed or lost.
Lighting a torch with flint and steel is a full-round action, and lighting any other fire with them takes at least that long.
This rope has 4 hit points and can be burst with a DC 24 Strength check. It is so supple that it provides a +2 circumstance bonus on Use Rope checks.

A torch burns for 1 hour, clearly illuminating a 20-foot radius and providing shadowy illumination out to a 40-foot radius. If a torch is used in combat, treat it as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a gauntlet of its size, plus 1 point of fire damage.

A pint of oil burns for 6 hours in a lantern. You can use a flask of oil as a splash weapon. Use the rules for alchemist’s fire, except that it takes a full round action to prepare a flask with a fuse. Once it is thrown, there is a 50% chance of the flask igniting successfully.

You can pour a pint of oil on the ground to cover an area 5 feet square, provided that the surface is smooth. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 1d3 points of fire damage to each creature in the area.
Throwing a grappling hook successfully requires a Use Rope check (DC 10, +2 per 10 feet of distance thrown).
This outfit includes a shirt with buttons, a skirt or pants with a drawstring, shoes, and perhaps a cap or hat. It may also include a belt or a leather or cloth apron for carrying tools.

A quarterstaff is a double weapon. You can fight with it as if fighting with two weapons, but if you do, you incur all the normal attack penalties associated with fighting with two weapons, just as if you were using a one-handed weapon and a light weapon. A creature wielding a quarterstaff in one hand can’t use it as a double weapon only one end of the weapon can be used in any given round.
The quarterstaff is a special monk weapon. This designation gives a monk wielding a quarterstaff special options.
You draw a light crossbow back by pulling a lever. Loading a light crossbow is a move action that provokes attacks of opportunity.

Normally, operating a light crossbow requires two hands. However, you can shoot, but not load, a light crossbow with one hand at a -2 penalty on attack rolls. You can shoot a light crossbow with each hand, but you take a penalty on attack rolls as if attacking with two light weapons. This penalty is cumulative with the penalty for one-handed firing.
A crossbow bolt used as a melee weapon is treated as a light improvised weapon (-4 penalty on attack rolls) and deals damage as a dagger of its size (crit ×2).
Bolts come in a wooden case that holds 10 bolts (or 5, for a repeating crossbow).
A bolt that hits its target is destroyed; one that misses has a 50% chance of being destroyed or lost.

A spellcaster with a spell component pouch is assumed to have all the material components and focuses needed for spellcasting, except for those components that have a specific cost, divine focuses, and focuses that wouldn’t fit in a pouch.
Perfect for a scholar, this outfit includes a robe, a belt, a cap, soft shoes, and possibly a cloak.
A spellbook has 100 pages of parchment, and each spell takes up one page per spell level (one page each for 0-level spells).
This is black ink. You can buy ink in other colors, but it costs twice as much.

id-00001.description: You fire a small orb of acid at the target. You must succeed on a ranged touch attack to hit your target. The orb deals 1d3 points of acid damage.
id-00001.name: Acid Splash

id-00002.description:
This spell allows you to inscribe your personal rune or mark, which can consist of no more than six characters. The writing can be visible or invisible. An arcane mark spell enables you to etch the rune upon any substance without harm to the material upon which it is placed. If an invisible mark is made, a detect magic spell causes it to glow and be visible, though not necessarily understandable. 

See invisibility, true seeing , a gem of seeing , or a robe of eyes likewise allows the user to see an invisible arcane mark. A read magic spell reveals the words, if any. The mark cannot be dispelled, but it can be removed by the caster or by an erase spell. 

If an arcane mark is placed on a living being, normal wear gradually causes the effect to fade in about a month. 

Arcane mark must be cast on an object prior to casting instant summons on the same object (see that spell description for details).
id-00002.effect: One personal rune or mark, all of which must fit within 1 sq. ft.
id-00002.name: Arcane Mark
id-00002.shortdescription: Inscribes a personal rune (visible or invisible).

id-00003.description: Depending on the version selected, you create up to four lights that resemble lanterns or torches (and cast that amount of light), or up to four glowing spheres of light (which look like will-o'-wisps), or one faintly glowing, vaguely humanoid shape. The dancing lights must stay within a 10-foot-radius area in relation to each other but otherwise move as you desire (no concentration required): forward or back, up or down, straight or turning corners, or the like. The lights can move up to 100 feet per round. A light winks out if the distance between you and it exceeds the spell's range. \n\nDancing lights can be made permanent with a permanency spell.
id-00003.effect: Up to four lights, all within a 10- ft.-radius area
id-00003.name: Dancing Lights

id-00004.description: This enchantment clouds the mind of a humanoid creature with 4 or fewer Hit Dice so that it takes no actions. Humanoids of 5 or more HD are not affected. A dazed subject is not stunned, so attackers get no special advantage against it. \n\nMaterial Component: A pinch of wool or similar substance.
id-00004.effect: One humanoid creature of 4 HD or less
id-00004.name: Daze
id-00004.shortdescription: Humanoid creature of 4 HD or less loses next action.

id-00005.description:
You detect magical auras. The amount of information revealed depends on how long you study a particular area or subject. 

1st Round: Presence or absence of magical auras. 

2nd Round: Number of different magical auras and the power of the most potent aura. 

3rd Round: The strength and location of each aura. If the items or creatures bearing the auras are in line of sight, you can make Spellcraft skill checks to determine the school of magic involved in each. (Make one check per aura; DC 15 + spell level, or 15 + half caster level for a nonspell effect.) 

Magical areas, multiple types of magic, or strong local magical emanations may distort or conceal weaker auras. 

Aura Strength: An aura's power depends on a spell's functioning spell level or an item's caster level. If an aura falls into more than one category, detect magic indicates the stronger of the two. 

[ ] [Aura Power ] 
[Source ] [Faint ] [Moderate ] [Strong ] [Overwhelming ] 
[Spell ] [0 - 3rd ] [4th-6th ] [7th-9th ] [10th+ ] 
[Magic item ] [1st-5th ] [6th-11th ] [12th-20th ] [21st+ ] 

Lingering Aura: A magical aura lingers after its original source dissipates (in the case of a spell) or is destroyed (in the case of a magic item). If detect magic is cast and directed at such a location, the spell indicates an aura strength of dim (even weaker than a faint aura). How long the aura lingers at this dim level depends on its original power: 

[Original Strength ] [Duration of Lingering Aura ] 
[Faint ] [1d6 rounds ] 
[Moderate ] [1d6 minutes ] 
[Strong ] [1d6x10 minutes ] 
[Overwhelming ] [1d6 days ] 

Outsiders and elementals are not magical in themselves, but if they are summoned, the conjuration spell registers. 

Each round, you can turn to detect magic in a new area. The spell can penetrate barriers, but 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt blocks it. 

Detect magic can be made permanent with a permanency spell.
id-00005.name: Detect Magic
id-00005.shortdescription: Detects spells and magic items within 60 ft.

id-00006.description: You determine whether a creature, object, or area has been poisoned or is poisonous. You can determine the exact type of poison with a DC 20 Wisdom check. A character with the Craft (alchemy) skill may try a DC 20 Craft (alchemy) check if the Wisdom check fails, or may try the Craft (alchemy) check prior to the Wisdom check. \n\nThe spell can penetrate barriers, but 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt blocks it.
id-00006.effect: One creature, one object, or a 5-ft. cube
id-00006.name: Detect Poison
id-00006.shortdescription: Detects poison in one creature or object.

id-00007.description: You direct a ray of positive energy. You must make a ranged touch attack to hit, and if the ray hits an undead creature, it deals 1d6 points of damage to it.
id-00007.name: Disrupt Undead

id-00008.description: This cantrip creates a burst of light. If you cause the light to burst directly in front of a single creature, that creature is dazzled for 1 minute unless it makes a successful Fortitude save. Sightless creatures, as well as creatures already dazzled, are not affected by flare .
id-00008.name: Flare
id-00008.shortdescription: Dazzles one creature (-1 on attack rolls).

id-00009.description:
Ghost sound allows you to create a volume of sound that rises, recedes, approaches, or remains at a fixed place. You choose what type of sound ghost sound creates when casting it and cannot thereafter change the sound's basic character. 

The volume of sound created depends on your level. You can produce as much noise as four normal humans per caster level (maximum twenty humans). Thus, talking, singing, shouting, walking, marching, or running sounds can be created. The noise a ghost sound spell produces can be virtually any type of sound within the volume limit. A horde of rats running and squeaking is about the same volume as eight humans running and shouting. A roaring lion is equal to the noise from sixteen humans, while a roaring dire tiger is equal to the noise from twenty humans. 

Ghost sound can enhance the effectiveness of a silent image spell. 

Ghost sound can be made permanent with a permanency spell. 

Material Component: A bit of wool or a small lump of wax.
id-00009.name: Ghost Sound

id-00010.description:
This spell causes an object to glow like a torch, shedding bright light in a 20-foot radius (and dim light for an additional 20 feet) from the point you touch. The effect is immobile, but it can be cast on a movable object. Light taken into an area of magical darkness does not function. 

A light spell (one with the light descriptor) counters and dispels a darkness spell (one with the darkness descriptor) of an equal or lower level. 

Arcane Material Component: A firefly or a piece of phosphorescent moss.
id-00010.name: Light

id-00011.description: You point your finger at an object and can lift it and move it at will from a distance. As a move action, you can propel the object as far as 15 feet in any direction, though the spell ends if the distance between you and the object ever exceeds the spell's range.
id-00011.effect: One nonmagical, unattended object weighing up to 5 lb.
id-00011.name: Mage Hand

id-00012.description: Mending repairs small breaks or tears in objects (but not warps, such as might be caused by a warp wood spell). It will weld broken metallic objects such as a ring, a chain link, a medallion, or a slender dagger, providing but one break exists. \n\nCeramic or wooden objects with multiple breaks can be invisibly rejoined to be as strong as new. A hole in a leather sack or a wineskin is completely healed over by mending. The spell can repair a magic item, but the item's magical abilities are not restored. The spell cannot mend broken magic rods, staffs, or wands, nor does it affect creatures (including constructs).
id-00012.effect: One object of up to 1 lb.
id-00012.name: Mending
id-00012.shortdescription: Makes minor repairs on an object.

id-00013.description:
You can whisper messages and receive whispered replies with little chance of being overheard. You point your finger at each creature you want to receive the message. When you whisper, the whispered message is audible to all targeted creatures within range. Magical silence, 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal (or a thin sheet of lead), or 3 feet of wood or dirt blocks the spell. The message does not have to travel in a straight line. It can circumvent a barrier if there is an open path between you and the subject, and the path's entire length lies within the spell's range. The creatures that receive the message can whisper a reply that you hear. The spell transmits sound, not meaning. It doesn't transcend language barriers. 

Note: To speak a message, you must mouth the words and whisper, possibly allowing observers the opportunity to read your lips. 

Focus: A short piece of copper wire.
id-00013.name: Message

id-00014.description: You can open or close (your choice) a door, chest, box, window, bag, pouch, bottle, barrel, or other container. If anything resists this activity (such as a bar on a door or a lock on a chest), the spell fails. In addition, the spell can only open and close things weighing 30 pounds or less. Thus, doors, chests, and similar objects sized for enormous creatures may be beyond this spell's ability to affect. \n\nFocus: A brass key.
id-00014.effect: Object weighing up to 30 lb. or portal that can be opened or closed
id-00014.name: Open/Close
id-00014.shortdescription: Opens or closes small or light things.

id-00015.description: Prestidigitations are minor tricks that novice spellcasters use for practice. Once cast, a prestidigitation spell enables you to perform simple magical effects for 1 hour. The effects are minor and have severe limitations. A prestidigitation can slowly lift 1 pound of material. It can color, clean, or soil items in a 1-foot cube each round. It can chill, warm, or flavor 1 pound of nonliving material. It cannot deal damage or affect the concentration of spellcasters. Prestidigitation can create small objects, but they look crude and artificial. The materials created by a prestidigitation spell are extremely fragile, and they cannot be used as tools, weapons, or spell components. Finally, a prestidigitation lacks the power to duplicate any other spell effects. Any actual change to an object (beyond just moving, cleaning, or soiling it) persists only 1 hour.
id-00015.name: Prestidigitation

id-00016.description: A ray of freezing air and ice projects from your pointing finger. You must succeed on a ranged touch attack with the ray to deal damage to a target. The ray deals 1d3 points of cold damage.
id-00016.name: Ray of Frost

id-00017.description:
By means of read magic, you can decipher magical inscriptions on objects - books, scrolls, weapons, and the like - that would otherwise be unintelligible. This deciphering does not normally invoke the magic contained in the writing, although it may do so in the case of a cursed scroll. Furthermore, once the spell is cast and you have read the magical inscription, you are thereafter able to read that particular writing without recourse to the use of read magic. You can read at the rate of one page (250 words) per minute. The spell allows you to identify a glyph of warding with a DC 13 Spellcraft check, a greater glyph of warding with a DC 16 Spellcraft check, or any symbol spell with a Spellcraft check (DC 10 + spell level). 

Read magic can be made permanent with a permanency spell. 

Focus: A clear crystal or mineral prism.
id-00017.level: Brd 0, Clr 0, Drd 0, Pal 1, Rgr 1, Sor/Wiz 0
id-00017.name: Read Magic

id-00018.description:
You imbue the subject with magical energy that protects it from harm, granting it a +1 resistance bonus on saves. 

Resistance can be made permanent with a permanency spell. 

Arcane Material Component: A miniature cloak.
id-00018.name: Resistance
id-00018.shortdescription: Subject gains +1 bonus on saving throws.

id-00019.description:
You channel negative energy through your touch, fatiguing the target. You must succeed on a touch attack to strike a target. 

The subject is immediately fatigued for the spell's duration. 

This spell has no effect on a creature that is already fatigued. Unlike with normal fatigue, the effect ends as soon as the spell's duration expires. 

Material Component: A drop of sweat.
id-00019.name: Touch of Fatigue

id-00001.description:
A missile of magical energy darts forth from your fingertip and strikes its target, dealing 1d4+1 points of force damage. 

The missile strikes unerringly, even if the target is in melee combat or has less than total cover or total concealment. Specific parts of a creature can't be singled out. Inanimate objects are not damaged by the spell. 

For every two caster levels beyond 1st, you gain an additional missile - two at 3rd level, three at 5th, four at 7th, and the maximum of five missiles at 9th level or higher. If you shoot multiple missiles, you can have them strike a single creature or several creatures. A single missile can strike only one creature. You must designate targets before you check for spell resistance or roll damage.
id-00001.effect: Up to five creatures, no two of which can be more than 15 ft. apart
id-00001.name: Magic Missile
id-00001.shortdescription: 1d4+1 damage; +1 missile per two levels above 1st (max 5).

id-00002.description:
A sleep spell causes a magical slumber to come upon 4 Hit Dice of creatures. Creatures with the fewest HD are affected first. 

Among creatures with equal HD, those who are closest to the spell's point of origin are affected first. Hit Dice that are not sufficient to affect a creature are wasted. 

Sleeping creatures are helpless. Slapping or wounding awakens an affected creature, but normal noise does not. Awakening a creature is a standard action (an application of the aid another action). 

Sleep does not target unconscious creatures, constructs, or undead creatures. 

Material Component: A pinch of fine sand, rose petals, or a live cricket.
id-00002.effect: One or more living creatures within a 10-ft.-radius burst
id-00002.name: Sleep
id-00002.shortdescription: Puts 4 HD of creatures into magical slumber.

id-00003.description:
An unseen servant is an invisible, mindless, shapeless force that performs simple tasks at your command. It can run and fetch things, open unstuck doors, and hold chairs, as well as clean and mend. The servant can perform only one activity at a time, but it repeats the same activity over and over again if told to do so as long as you remain within range. It can open only normal doors, drawers, lids, and the like. It has an effective Strength score of 2 (so it can lift 20 pounds or drag 100 pounds). It can trigger traps and such, but it can exert only 20 pounds of force, which is not enough to activate certain pressure plates and other devices. It can't perform any task that requires a skill check with a DC higher than 10 or that requires a check using a skill that can't be used untrained. Its speed is 15 feet. 

The servant cannot attack in any way; it is never allowed an attack roll. It cannot be killed, but it dissipates if it takes 6 points of damage from area attacks. (It gets no saves against attacks.) If you attempt to send it beyond the spell's range (measured from your current position), the servant ceases to exist. 

Material Component: A piece of string and a bit of wood.
id-00003.name: Unseen Servant

text.p: The Cathedral of Dinor stands on the Island of Spirits, a small rocky island accessible from the town proper via a sturdy stone bridge. Numerous statues, benches and paved paths once stood on the island, but have long since been taken away or fallen into disrepair, leaving behind pedestals and piles of stones.
text.frame: The bridge rises above the waters between the island and the town center. As you get closer, the cathedral, with its twin towers, looms high above you. Old paths, taken up as fishing trails, cross the edges of the island, dwarfed by the bulk of the huge building.
text.p: The cathedral consists of two tower spires on both sides of the entrance. The purpose of the towers is mainly achitectural, and they contain nothing other than broad staircases and high ceilinged rooms, now completely empty.
text.frame: The Cathedral is a disproportionate building in today's Dinor. Although the rest of the once glorious city is mostly ruins the Cathedral is in good shape. It fills nearly half of the Island of Spirits and only the dark silhoutte of the nearby mountains prevents it from being seen from a huge distance over the Faithful Water. The entrance of the Cathedral faces the bridge connecting the island to the city.
text.p: The PCs enter the Cathedral through the main door, which is usually closed but not locked.

Allan tries to convince the PCs to take a mission - a different mission than the one he is actually on - but nevertheless necessary for the completion of his own goals. Allan is actually after the Cube of Raughnar. He needs the party to get rid of whatever might be guarding the Cube. He suspects also that the Bowl of Tulan is left in the Cathedral to guard the Cube.
Allan might choose to make the following "conversation".

Hint : Open Allan's personality sheet first and click the bubble icon. This way you can have the conversation as Allan. The identity in boldface is the active one. You can also do this by dragging the chat frame onto the identity list.
text.frame: AllanGood evening, my name is Allan. May I join you for a cup of tea or wine, perhaps, on my expense of course.
AllanWaitress, two bottles of the old Kendar walley red and a kettle of tea!
AllanAnd a pot of whatever it is that gives that wonderful smell!

AllanSo, where were we, oh yes, as you have surely heard, a miner was slaughtered three days ago. I have conducted some preliminary investigations and in fact, I might have a little something for you to do - if you are interested in helping me and these people and earning a little pocket money, too.

AllanI have a reason to believe that there is more to the Cathedral than these people know about. It once was a great site of worship of Tulan, a god now all but forgotten. The Bowl of Tulan, however, is an artifact that would benefit any church aligned towards the good. I'm not a priest and I do not want it for myself, but it is very valuable and many people, both good and evil, would like to lay their hands on it.

AllanIt is possible that the breaking of the seals of the Cathedral last year has encouraged all kind of people to try their luck. I know of one other incident that happened nearby recently, which makes it at least two. Coincidence? Maybe, but I'm no great believer in coincidence. Anyway, one pair of eyes sees less than several, and you could maybe find out if the Bowl is somehow connected to these events. If you decide to help in unraveling this terrible mystery, the townspeople would like to hire each of you with 10 gold pieces. If you, or I, solve this crime, the authorities of Andegar will certainly reward us, too. So, if you decide to commit to this charge, just let me know.
text.p: Note that Allan avoids topics that he doesn't care to tell the PCs about rather than lie outright.

text.frame: The main hall of the cathedral rises high above, ending in arches connecting the huge pillars supporting the roof. The area has been stripped of everything that can be carried away, the light streaming in through tall windows at the other end of the hall, above the place where an altar stands, empty of decorations.
text.p: The interior of the church is really quite simple, a rectangular space with an array of huge columns supporting the arched gable roof. The floor shows markings from benches that once filled the area now scattered with crates and barrels. When the Cathedral was sealed, all valuable items were naturally taken away (including the marble interior walls that made up the side chapels).

Two of the eight colums hold secret doors, the first and the last ones on the left, looking in from the main doors. The first one is essentially a hollowed out piece of masonry that fits the column at the edges, and has a Search DC of 24. This staircase is quite wide, almost fitting two men abreast.

The other secret door is in the fourth column on the left, the one closest to the altar. This column has a booth for preaching the priests used to use, and is accessible through an open staircase built along the side of the column. In the booth, a panel swings open to reveal a narrow staircase upwards. The Search DC to find this door is 15.
text.frame: As you climb into the preacher's box, you start tapping on the wooden panels along the wall. Sure enough, one section seems to be hollow, and before long you discover a latch that reveals a narrow spiral staircase leading upwards inside the column.

p.i: There is a staircase token in the token box (only in the GMs box). Use it if and when either the players or Allan finds the staircase. If Allan's help is required, he will show PCs the stairs in the back of the Cathedral (leading to the Chapel room in the second floor).

text.p: If the party takes the underground river from the Cathedral's basement, they will head into the mines outside Dinor.

The entry point is rather deep in the mines, behind most of the collapses that happened after the Devastation. The mines have now been taken over by a group of goblins, who found the area by chance and came down through the overflow pipe in one of the rooms in the area.
The goblins are trying to clear the rubble in order to loot the upper reaches of the mines, and maybe even try and raid the town itself, using the mines as a hideout.

p.i: As the tactical situation on the map may be essential, the use of tokens and different pointers is beneficial. The tactical movement, range of weapons and spells as well as the effect areas are convenietly visulized by overlaying a grid on the map. After that the area pointers (square, circle and cone) shade the grid-squares they fall upon.

Another important feature is the mask. Turn on the masked mode with the radial menu and "lasso" the area you want to show the players. Then share the image. To reveal more area, "lasso" the area wanted and the area will be revealed.
Moreover, you can switch the area shown to the players by panning the image to the view you wish and then re-sharing the image.

Whenever a fight breaks out, remember to take advantage of the combat tracker. It can be opened from the top right corner of the screen, using the icon resembling a list of entries. You can drag any PC from his or her portrait, NPCs from the personality list or monsters from the monster list to the tracker to add them to it. You can collect initiative rolls here and sort the view according to initiative, and keep track of wounds.

Once the PC have explored this area, they will enter the upper reaches of the mines. This section is not detailed here, but an overview map is provided, should the GM wish to improvise or prepare this section on his own.

Should you wish to improvise, a good idea might be to use the map as a guide, and draw smaller sections on blank drawings. To do this, open the images and maps list scroll and hit new. A blank drawing will be created that you can share with your players.

linklist.link: Overview map of the upper mines

text.p: The secret staircase in the first colum also leads to the catacombs beneath the Cathedral. While it is reasonable to assume they exist, their entrance and existence has been forgotten long since.
text.frame: As you descend the spiraling stair lower and lower, the air starts to get humid and rancid. As the stairs end in a rough chamber with some burial coffins, you can clearly hear the sound of an underground stream flowing closeby. A corridor leads away from the chamber, blocked by a sturdy stone door. Another corridor, of natural stone, leads to the wet darkness, blocked by an iron portcullis and a lever on the wall on this side of it.
text.p: Beside the underwater river there is a lever. Pulling the lever does nothing, but pushing it back to its initial position rises the portcullis blocking the way to the river. After the bars have risen, they start to slowly fall back down, to close behind passing cargo. In fact, the portcullis was originally meant to facilitate loading barrels going downriver and unloading cargo from upriver.

There are no boats available. The PCs can either swim (the distance to the underground lake is 3 miles), or they can use wooden coffins found in the entrance chamber as vessels. The larger coffins in the grave area, however, might hold a zombie or a skeleton that will fight when disturbed.

p.i: As an option for the GM, you may wish to elaborate the area of the catacombs and populate it with an undead menace. See the section on the mines for some useful hints in proceeding with the exporation, should you decide to do so.

text.p: A journal can be found in the catacombs. You may add information in the journal if you want to.
Both of the secret doors lead to the second floor. The second floor, Chapel floor, is built above the arch-heads and its existence is difficult to notice from below.

p.i: This area contains a section the players cannot see at first glance. Use the masking feature here, to reveal only the part the PCs can see when they initially enter the area. Once you have opened the map, use the radial menu to enable masking, "lasso" the area of the room the PCs are in, and share the image to the players using the radial menu.

text.p: The second floor is divided into two compartments with an illusionary wall. The bigger part (in the rear part of the church), is arranged as a chapel meant for private ceremonies of the clergy.

Beside the staircase stand two large human statues (stone golems). The staircase is wide enough for the golems to walk easily. What the PCs do not know, is that if the door below is closed, the Balor cannot pass.
text.frame: You come to a large room below the huge roof of the cathedral. At one end, two large human statues stand on each side of a staircase emerging from one of the pillars supporting the roof. At the other, an altar stands, faintly illuminated by a glow from an unseen light source. A large bowl, seemingly made of red marble, rests on the altar. A low tingling voice emanates from the walls, floor and ceiling.
text.p: The bowl on the altar is the Bowl of Tulan.

The smaller compartment holds another 'altar' on which the Cube of Raughnar rests. Upon passing the illusionary wall or otherwise entering the space beyond the chapel compartment, the golems start approaching. They will not attack the PCs, or even defend themselves, should they be able to damage them. The golems are there to to prevent any hostile behaviour on the part of creatures summonded from the cube (such asthe Balor). When the Balor attacks, the goblins retaliate immediately.
Spotting the wall as illusionary has a Spot DC of 20.
text.frame: As you move into and through the wall behind the altar, you emerge in another, smaller room. A small and dirty window in the back wall gives the room some light and you can make out an opening into another, narrower staircase in a pillar here. The room also houses another altar, right next to the illusionary wall. On it rests a small bronze cube, with a different fantastic face depicted on each one of its sides.
text.p: There is a narrow and low staircase in the cube room, too small for the golems (and a Balor).
text.frame: You move in the room, feeling a presence building in the direction of the cube on the altar. As you watch, shapes of limbs and horns start bulging out of the surface of the cube. It seems like a handful of creatures fighting an unseen struggle, but a huge demonic being quickly starts gaining shape over the others. Soon it becomes obvious that the demonic shape will pull himself completely free of the cube in just moments.
text.p: After the scene, the PCs have a round of activity before the Balor has completely emerged from the cube. After this round has passed, the golems will attack the balor and it will retaliate.
text.frame: As soon as the demon pulls its legs completely free from the cube, the two statues standing next to it burst into action, attacking it with tremendeous force. The demon responds by bursting into living flame and lashing out with a fiery whip that emerges in its hand. You cringe back from the flames as the three start their fight, the floor of the room pounding under the creatures' heavy feet.
text.p: The staircase leads to the catacombs, but a keen eye (DC 30) can spot a door to the Hall also. If the players don't understand that fleeing is their only option, you might want to encourage them.

Allan's secret ambition is to get the cube into his possession. His plan is to use the PCs to trigger the guardians, and go after the cube after it goes tranquil for a period. He will use his stealth to get to it unnoticed, and does know about the secret door in the first column.

p.i: Because the purpose of this campaign is to act as inspiration and a demonstration, it is left open to the Gamemaster what Allan's final plans are, and how to finish this adventure. Perhaps he will escape mysteriously, maybe the balor will take him over while still in the town area, escaping to the west with a trail of bodies in his wake.

text.p: A long time ago, Dinor was a flourishing city, its mines pouring riches on its people. With the wealth, came merchants, and following them, aristocracy, craftsmen, and priests. With the domains reasonably safe from invasion, guarded by the dwarves in the mountains and the men of the western cities, the wealth was spent lavishly, culminating in the building of the Cathedral.

The Cathedral of Tulan stood as the landmark by the Faithful Water and the Cathedral was rich with glass paintings, expensive woods heavy with gilt and the misty clouds drifting in the clear crystal of Bowl of Tulan were a wonder people came to admire from lands far away.

But the pride brought corruption and ambition brought the Year of Devastation. People fled with whatever they could take with them as the highest clergy tried to correct things with their cause, the Cube of Raughnar. As they asked guidance (the use of Raughnar's cube started with greedy questions of ever better places to mine), terrible horrors occasionally escaped. In the last day of the Devastation, the high priests sacrificed upon the Bowl of Tulan, isolated the Cube and finally sealed the Cathedral.
In the following few years, the mines were exploited without paying proper attention to supporting the caverns. Sadly, this resulted in a series of collapses practically destroying the mines.

After the mass flight, the following decades saw a steady stream of refugees leaving Dinor. The income from the mines deteriorated constantly and fertile farmlands were in the west, on the plains near Fabrad. The old caravan route following the Faithful Waters and up the river into the mountains still brought some merchants into Dinor for trade, but most of them moved on to the growing city of Andegar, where the demand was high for the luxuries brought from beyond the great desert.

A century after the Devastation, Dinor was much in the condition it is today; most of the houses taken apart, the stones transported to Andegar and other cities. It is a short rest for the caravans coming from the mountains or the last bed before the harsh route. Faithful Waters provides a fair catch of fish for the small town and the gardens planted during the greatness of Dinor yield fruit and pasture for cattle. A small foundry and on the outskirts of today's Dinor still makes the best pots and roasters by the lake. Also the nearby smithy makes masterwork weapons and armor.

id-00015.name: GM notes on current events in Dinor

text.p: Three days ago a miner was found brutally slaughtered in the mines (two miles to the south of Dinor). The four other men working there at the time are under custody; none of them resisted the detention, but all have claimed to be innocent. The miner was actually killed by goblins having burrowed through a collapsed corridor with the help of one of the Ankhegs they have captured. No one has been to the mines since the incident.

Yesterday evening, "Lord" Allan came to the town and took residence at the Inn, 'Lost Pipes'. He said he did not come for the murder, but has promised to investigate the matter and has also provided Dinor a loan of 500 gold pieces until the representatives of Andegar arrive. Actually, Allan did not introduce himself as a Lord but he purposefully gave the people that impression.

Allan is in fact an assassin (rogue) having researched Dinor ever since the villagers opened the Cathedral a year ago. It is now used as a storage for lake transport and that initially raised Allan's interest. He reckoned that old constructions often hide secret passages, tunnels and in the case of Cathedrals, catacombs. He started investigating the history of Dinor in order to find a way to lay hands on some of the items stored there, without being seen, using, for example, long forgotten tunnels. Rummaging through the storerooms of the Republic Library of Andegar, he found old scrolls written during the Year of Devastation and concluded that the Cube of Raughnar might still be in the Cathedral of Tulan in Dinor (now called the Cathedral of Dinor).

linklist.link: A possible conversation when the PCs enter the Inn.

text.p: Hint: Open Peter's personality sheet and click the bubble icon. This way you can have the conversation as Peter. The identity in boldface is the active one.
text.frame: PeterGreetings dear people. I'm Peter Hammock, I welcome you heartily to my humble inn. Are you hungry or perhaps sleepy, or may I recommend a nice bottle of wine together with my own specialty cheese? But, please, first make yourselves comfortable wherever you wish.

PeterNow, do you have everything you need? Oh boy, sooner or later you will hear it... so let me tell you. Three days ago the miner's foreman brought poor Jeller, a local miner ' living, oh my, who lived by the West Fields, home slaughtered. All the miners are, mind me, now under custody and almost everybody has been heard, so you should not worry about my inn's security ' anyway, we have locked doors during the nights since then. I personally don't think the miners are behind it, they might occasionally cause some trouble but never anything that couldn't be settled with bare fists. My wife, Lily, blames the village council and says that it was an ill deed to open the Cathedral. Don't pay any heed to her, she's superstitious and doesn't like change - probably she's just scared because old Tim claimed to have heard odd bangs from beneath the Hall floor when arranging crates. Old Tim is so deaf he wouldn't hear a horn blown under his nose.

PeterYou see that Lord over there, he's Lord Allan. He arrived yesterday evening and a good thing that he did! Now, he's investigating the murder until we get someone from Andegar to take charge. It was very fortunate that he showed up just now when things got a turn to the worst. And believe me or not, he provided us with 500 gold pieces, just a loan, you understand, but a goodly money for us to hire help to solve the murder. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go to the stables. If you need anything, just call one of the maids. But no tricks, they are all my daughters and fine girls they are.
text.p: Allan could join the PCs at this stage.
The Lost Pipes Inn is situated on the main square of the town, next to the bridge leading to the cathedral.
It can be assumed that the PCs end up here, it being the only place in town with a room for rent, and most of the townsfolk being a little paranoid thanks to the murders at the mines.
text.frame: 'Lost Pipes', Dinor's only tavern, is a former locksmiths' guild-house. The common room of the Pipes is dimly lit by three large fireplaces, the columns interrupting the sizy space casting shadows giving privacy to the guests. The aged furnishings of the room are worn here and there but the general cleanliness makes it feel sophisticated rather than grubby.
text.p: The first floor is devoted to the tavern and kitchens, whereas Peter Hammock's family lives in the second. In the third floor are guest rooms (plenty of those). Master Hammock thinks that living in the second floor himself gives his night-guests peace regardless of the behaviour of his customers in the common room. The fourth floor hasn't been used in Peter's lifetime.
The Pipes is a family business. Mr. and Mrs. Hammock and three of their daughters work at the Inn. In addition Rose's husband Ylfur is helping Peter in the stables.
text.frame: The proprietor, a tall and burly man constantly humming to himself stands at a table in one corner of the room, next to a doorway that leads to the kitchens, judging by the sounds. As you enter, he takes a couple of steps in your direction and opens his arms welcomingly.
text.p: Mr. Hammock is a talkative fellow, and will start babbling about current events as soon as any PC approaches him

Before you start, it is recommended you read the Fantasy Grounds user manual, and familiarize yourself with the main interface.
The purpose of this campaign is to give you, as the Gamemaster, a glimpse at the various tools you have at your disposal for running games using Fantasy Grounds.
Reading these pages, you will see examples, and brief instructions on the most convenient methods to use in various typical situations.
text.h: How to use the material in this campaign
text.p: This book contains an introduction to an adventure in the town of Dinor. This is intended to work as a starting point, and is not a complete adventure. For downloadable content such as adventures, check out the Fantasy Grounds website at http://www.fantasygrounds.com.

The bulk of the material presented is here in the Story Book. You can create a hot key to any page you find here by dragging the icon in the top left corner of the sheet onto any of the 96 slots on the hot key bar. Use the links in the pages to navigate from a page to another, and to find items and maps related to the section at hand.
You can naturally make your own notes, items, events and NPCs and so on. The material presented in this adventure may be of help to you when you learn what you can do with Fantasy Grounds.

If you wish, you can organize all the data on the list scrolls into categories. Access the radial menu on the small tabs at the bottom of the scroll to add and edit categories, and just drag the icon representing an entry on a tab to move it there.
A sturdy journal, bound in thick leather with pages of what once was fine paper is now mostly ruined by moisture.
Some of the tome is written in a foreign language you don't understand. Only the final page, written in skilled handwriting, is readable:

"Today it ends. The high priest will be sacrificed. It is saddening that there is no other way to end this devastation. In one undertaking, however necessary, we'll lose the Cathedral, the High Priest, and the Bowl. Of course it is the right thing to do, but will the Bowl protect the world forever from the evil of the Cube of Raughnar? I doubt it. However well we might guard the Cathedral, someday the watch may be forgotten. Tulan bless us, at least soon the horrors cannot pass the borders of this holy place."

text.frame: The flow of the river through the darkness of the mountain roots slows down as you suddenly enter a large cavern. In the farther end of the hall the bottom of the lake climbs gently, but the shore shows clear signs that the water is not always this low. In the middle of the lake is a vigorous whirlpool, but there is still plenty of time to catch one of the rust-eaten chains attached to a stone wharf on the left before its pull gets too strong.
text.p: The water level of the pool varies significantly during the year, but now the water is low and the river flowing from underneath the Cathedral is usable by small boats. When the water is high, the tunnels near the lake fill up and even rise up the stairs, the overflow vent described below, made for the purpose.
The goblins in the mines use the pool as a source of water, but are afraid of the spider (see below) and it is unlikely any are in the area at any given time.
text.frame: The foul smell of decay increasingly stings your nostrils as you advance into the dark water-carved tunnel. The floor feels slippery and the walls seem somehow hairy.
Beyond a slight narrowing the tunnel preads into larger cave. Rotten carcases line the walls and thick webs are all over the cavern. At first glance, however, the cave seems otherwise empty.
text.p: There is a spider lurking above the doorway in the ceiling. It will surprise the PCs if not spotted (Hide bonus +7).
Give this description to the players as the PCs approach the first door from the direction of the river and the spider lair.
text.frame: The corridor forks to the right, before ending in a heavy stone door. The door overlaps its frame on all sides. Judging by the fine construction, it is quite likely this door has been built to withstand flooding from this side. You see no visible lock or bar, but a heavy iron pull ring is attached to the center.
text.p: The door is not locked, but it has not been opened for a long time. Pulling it open requires a DC 24 strength check, and three people can work on it at a time. If the door is opened, the grating sound will alert the goblins in the cavern behind it (see below).

The people of Dinor once worked with gnomes and dwarves in the mountains. The dwarven workers carved caverns in the mines to live in. The room with the stairs upward and the adjacent larger hall are evidence of this time.
text.frame: You see a rectangular room carved into the stone of the mountains. The ceiling rises above that of the rest of the mining shafts, to a height of about fifteen feet. Here and there, along the walls, can a decorative carving be seen, faded by the years. From the mud at the base of the walls, you can tell the underground river has probably flooded this area a number of times in the years.
In one corner of the room, a very narrow metal staircase spirals upwards, into an opening in the roof. Next to the stairway, sit three goblins, quietly talking.
text.p: The flood overflow vent, actually a staircase carved into the mountain, climbs all the way to the surface of the mountains in an inhospitable valley. Because of the seasonal overflowing of water, the valley is swampy. It was, in fact, a misjudgement in the engineering of the tower together with overly greedy mining that caused many parts of the mine to collapse.
Three goblins guard the room of the tower. If the PCs advance carefully they may hear bits of conversation, for instance.
text.frame: Goblin... still four nites before the enforcements arrive. Those builder idiots think they can defend the yard with the burrow-beasts but they aren't under control. I say, we go and take 'em back by force and give 'em a lesson on disobeying schedules, no? You, go wake up the captain...
text.p: If the PCs are not as careful, they'll tumble into the three goblins. If a fight breaks out, a goblin sergeant appears from the other door after three rounds.
The larger room next to the one described above is a larger room, once used as the main living area of the dwarves.
text.frame: You enter the hall through a heavy stone door left open, similar to the one you saw earlier blocking the corridor. Behind the door is a large room housing some hastily stacked mining tools and some sacks next to what appears to be rabbits and other food scavenged by the goblins.
text.p: This room houses the leader of the goblin bunch, and his sergeant. There are also other goblins here from time to time, usually one to three.
text.frame: As you step in, two goblins turn their heads from a crate they were inspecting. One draws his spear, as the other starts shouting something in what must be the goblin language.
text.p: The leader, a level 3 adept, will attempt to call in reinforcements from the cavern area (see below). The sergeant is determined to hold back the PCs with whatever other goblins are in the room until the reinforcements arrive.
In the large cavern behind the flood gates, a group of goblins are trying to clear the rubble blocking the way into the rest of the mines connecting the area to the entrance near the town.
text.frame: The passage opens into a larger hollowed out cavern, apparently used as a center of mining operations during the times these parts of the mines were active. In the other end of the room, working on a passage leading further, you see a group of five goblins working on clearing the rubble blocking the way there. Three of them are spread out holding iron chains attached to the neck of a large insect creature. As the three guide it by the chains, the two remaining goblins are herding it in the direction of the rubble with two long poles.
text.p: The goblins have captured a young ankheg and are trying to use it to burrow through the rubble. They have managed to clear a space wide enough for a medium size creature to pass though in the wider corridor, leading to the upper sections of the mines.

Should the ankheg get free, it will, unless attacked, fight the goblins next to it, and flee in the direction of the cleared out corridor. Handling the ankheg provokes a lot of noise out of the goblins, and a fight here will not alert the leader and sergeant in the hall, described above, unless some obvious sounds of intruders, such as explosions, are heard.

description.p: A head-sized cubical artifact having engraved faces on each side. The bronzy items weighs 50 lbs.
Once a day the Cube can be used to gain iinformation or special powers.

When a person sees the Cube he or she must make a will save (DC 10+, see below) or the strongest of the imprisoned creatures comes out of the Cube in two full rounds. The creatures held in the cube are aware of its function, and any evil creature summoned will most likely fight anyone in the area (or if there are several, all of them). If the creature cannot slay any living being during the next 20 rounds, before being forcefully drawn back in, the cube is inactive for the day. If the creature is slain, it returns to the cube and it must answer a single question to the best of its ability, or if it does not know the answer, say so. Each living being killed by the creature gives it an hour outside the Cube.

If the person seeing the Cube makes a successful save, she can press her face onto the cube and gain the appearance and (gradually) the abilities of the creature whose face she selected. The transformation granting full physical abilities takes one full round and the other abilities appear in one day. Each day after the transformation, however, the person must make a will save or be partly assimilated by the creature, roll d100 for the percentage of assimilation (also the mental traits are transferred). After the percentage reaches 100, the person is tranformed into the creature and her own spirit enters the cube.
When a person gets a form from the cube, her own face is engraved on it and can be treated as any other face. In a way, the Cube grants the imprisoned immortality, but at a great cost.
The DC of the will save is 10 + the level of the strongest creature bound to the Cube.
The Bowl is a potent artifact, a tool of magical rituals. When inactive the 200 lbs. bowl appears to be of clear crystal with drifting misty clouds inside. Its appearance changes when used.
Currently the Bowl seems to be made of dull red marble, this is because of a blood sacrifice.

The bowl can be used to channel Tulan's powers above the capabilities of the channeling priest (treat all spells as having +1 caster level, and maximized when doing Tulan's will in aiding her worshippers).

Its other ability is to channel Tulan's power to suppress an extraplanar or magical power. A sacrifice upon the bowl creates magical barrier in a single room that an outsider of a level below the level of the sacrifice cannot pass. The sacrificed creature must be willing and of approximately same alignment as Tulan (any good). A low tingling noise emanating from the barrier notifies the active area of the shield.
The extent of the barrier from the bowl is always less than the level of the sacrifice times 10 feet. The bowl cannot be used in two different ways at any given time.

A high priest of Tulan was sacrificed upon the bowl. The power of this sacrifice is potent enough to keep the Balor currently entrapped in the cube at bay.If the bowl is removed from the room, the barrier ceases to exist.

id-00001.name: Allan

text.p: Allan prides himself for being an analyst and having the discipline to pull through the lifestyle required to take advantage of his wits.

He always travels alone or in a convoy of strangers; a lonely man leaves less tracks for those who can read them. If he needs a party to accomplish a mission, he employs adventurers, suspicious lot who often are strangers themselves but who are known locally so as not to be related to him.

Another precaution is to never lie, at least in matters that a law-abiding person would not. Spells are not uncommon and he has accumulated a good deal of knowledge on them so he is not easily distracted by them. However, his boyishly amicable appearance makes him an easy acquaintance.

id-00001.treasure: Magic shortbow +2, Magic studded leather +2, 3x Potion of Undetectable Alignment, 2x Potion of Cat's Grace, shortsword

text.p: The inn-keeper of 'Lost Pipes'. He is married to Lily (Hammock), and they have four daughters: Violet, Rose, Pansy and Daisy.
Lives in the second floor of the inn building; that way, he says, the guests will not be troubled by the customers of the tavern in the ground floor (the guest lodging is in the third floor).
Peter is a man nice to those who cause no trouble, but is willing to use his cudgel to the less mannerly guests. His father was a miner who died when a tunnel collapsed.

p.i: This entry was created by dragging the goblin entry from the monster book to the NPC list. This is a convenient way to create individual creatures based on an existing template.

text.p: The leader of the goblins in the mines is an adept of third level. He is a cowardly leader, and usually gives out the more inconvenient tasks for his sergeant to handle.
In combat, he will try to call on as many of his troupe as possible, and engage from a distance, shouting orders.
If a PC approaches him, he will use his cause fear spell to try and scare them off, but if several advance on him, he will probably run for his life.
level 0: cure minor wounds, ghost sound, touch of fatigue
level 1: burning hands, cause fear
